newsitem.title: USA: Lake Elsinore, Calif., to restructure problem debt.
newsitem.headline: Lake Elsinore, Calif., to restructure problem debt.

text.p: Lake Elsinore, Calif., will be able to cover October payments to holders of $55 million of bonds and plans to restructure a portion of the debt to avert future problems, the city's attorney said on Tuesday.

"There is no potential for their being a default in October, and to prevent any future potential defaults, the city is in the process of restructuring the pool," said city attorney John Harper. The next bond payment is due on October 1.
As previously reported, Lake Elsinore has nearly depleted the reserve fund of the $55 million Marks-Roos bond pool due to the delinquencies of a major property owner.
The pool is made up of several Mello-Roos redevelopment agency bonds.

Harper said the city formed a work-out team of financial advisers and bond attorneys to develop a plan to restructure the pool. Harper said the restructuring could involve refunding a portion of the outstanding debt.
Last year, the Securities and Exchange Commission asked Lake Elsinore officials for documents related to the pool and the depleted reserve fund.
